summary_reasoning: The report contains multiple company-specific syntheses and at least two original theses with quantified implications and timelines. Notable syntheses include Tremfya’s >$5 billion peak sales by 2028 based on superiority vs Cosentyx, a margin trajectory that ties cost containment to Stelara patent erosion, and a modeled >$3 billion Stelara decline offset by oncology and immunology launches. Original theses include the explicit modeling of legal costs at 3% of non-GAAP net income along with a view that returning talc cases to tort reduces total payout but increases timing uncertainty, and a forward-looking tax-rate normalization thesis (toward ~21%) tied to tariffs and increased US manufacturing, plus a quantified 2025 $400 million tariff impact for J&J’s medtech. These are decision-relevant, company-distinct, and supported with mechanisms, numbers, and timelines (e.g., H2 2025 Caplyta close; 2025 tariff hit; 2028 Tremfya peaks). While some boilerplate appears (wide moat/diversification), the valuation incorporates novel drivers (tariffs, tax rate shifts, litigation costs, pipeline ramps). Overall, the balance of synthesized insights and original, quantified theses warrants an Excellent on originality.

insights_classified.text: We view Tremfya as well positioned for growth, leading to peak annual sales of over $5 billion by 2028; superiority vs Novartis’ Cosentyx.
Adjusted EPS growth ~4% next five years; flat operating margins as cost-containment offsets margin pressure from Stelara’s patent loss.
J&J expects a $400 million 2025 tariff impact (mostly medtech) and we increase the assumed long-term tax rate toward ~21% with US manufacturing shifts.
We model base-case annual legal costs at 3% of non-GAAP net income; returning talc claims to tort likely reduces total payout but increases timing uncertainty.
We assume >$3 billion decline in global Stelara sales in 2025, offset by dominance in multiple myeloma (Darzalex/Carvykti), Caplyta expansion, and new launches (TAR-200, icotrokinra).
Caplyta could reach nearly $5 billion annual sales by end of the 10-year period; acquisition expected to close in H2 2025; upside via MDD approval.
Diverse segments and strong free cash flow (>20% of sales) insulate J&J from downturns and patent losses; steady dividend track record.
Wide moat from IP and device switching costs; pricing reform risks not material to moat rating.

red_flags: Generic bulls/bears bullets without unique mechanisms
